elements.content: Five chiral and noncentrosymmetric metal–organic frameworks, namely, {[Co(TIPA)(trans-chdc)(H2O)]·H2O} n (1), {[Ni(TIPA)(trans-chdc)(H2O)]·H2O} n (2), {[Co(TIPA)(seb)1/2](NO3)·H2O} n (3), {[Ni(TIPA)(seb)1/27](NO3)·H2O} n (4), and {[Zn2(TIPA)(btc)(μ2-OH)]·4H2O} n (5), have been synthesized based on the N-center tripodal TIPA ligand, where TIPA is tris[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-phenyl]amine, H3btc is 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, trans-H2chdc is trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, and H2seb is sebacic acid. Complexes 1 and 2 are isostructural, crystallize in the chiral orthorhombic space group P212121, and contain a 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation based on (6,3) layers. The two sets of layers of subpolycatenation are interconnected by right-handed Co(trans-chdc) helical chain, forming a self-catenated framework. Complexes 3 and 4 are also isostructural and crystallize in the chiral monoclinic space group C2. They also contain a 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation based on (6,3) layers. Complex 5 crystallizes in the noncentrosymmetric space group Pna21. Similarly to complexes 1–4, it also contains a 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation based on (6,3) dinuclear Zn-TIPA layers. Meanwhile, the btc3– ligand with a trimonodentate coordination mode connects the dinuclear Zn unit to form a 2D (6,3) Zn-btc layer. The combination of the two types of interconnected 2D nets results in a self-catenated framework. SHG measurements on complexes 1–5 reveal that complexes 1 and 2 display modest SHG responses that are approximately 3 and 4 times that of KH2PO4 (KDP). The SHG responses of 3 and 4 are about the same as those of 1 and 2, respectively. Complex 5 has a strong SHG response, and its SHG efficiency is approximately 10 times that of KDP. In addition, the photoluminescent properties and thermal stabilities of these complexes were studied in the solid state.

elements.content: Five chiral and noncentrosymmetric metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) based on the N-center tripodal TIPA ligand that feature a 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation have been synthesized and characterized. The chirality and noncentrosymmetry of the complexes derive from the spontaneous resolution process. In addition, their related physical properties were also studied.
elements.clean_text: Five chiral and noncentrosymmetric metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based on the N-center tripodal TIPA ligand that feature a 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation have been synthesized and characterized. The chirality and noncentrosymmetry of the complexes derive from the spontaneous resolution process. In addition, their related physical properties were also studied.

elements.content: Enormous effort has been dedicated to the design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), not only for their intriguing aesthetic structures and topology but also for their potential applications as functional materials. It is well-known that the properties of MOFs depend significantly on their intrinsic structures. Therefore, the most important task currently is to identify correlations between the structures and properties of these materials. Obviously, such information plays an instructive role in the rational synthesis of certain functional MOFs with desirable properties. For instance, magnetic properties of MOFs are usually derived from paramagnetic metal bi-, tri-, or polynuclear units. Therefore, carboxylate ligands can be used to construct magnetic MOFs because the carboxylate group can induce core aggregation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Enormous effort has been dedicated to the design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), not only for their intriguing aesthetic structures and topology but also for their potential applications as functional materials. It is well-known that the properties of MOFs depend significantly on their intrinsic structures. Therefore, the most important task currently is to identify correlations between the structures and properties of these materials. Obviously, such information plays an instructive role in the rational synthesis of certain functional MOFs with desirable properties. For instance, magnetic properties of MOFs are usually derived from paramagnetic metal bi-, tri-, or polynuclear units. Therefore, carboxylate ligands can be used to construct magnetic MOFs because the carboxylate group can induce core aggregation.

elements.content: In recent years, materials with nonlinear optical (NLO) activity and ferroelectric properties have become increasingly attractive because of their versatile applicability in optoelectronic devices, photonics technologies, semiconductor chips, and microwave devices. Generally, chiral and noncentrosymmetric (NCS) MOFs usually exhibit NLO properties. When their space groups are among the 10 polar point groups C 1, C s , C 2, C 2v , C 4, C 4v , C 3, C 3v , C 6, and C 6v , they can even simultaneously exhibit both second harmonic generation (SHG) and ferroelectricity properties. As is well-known, a basic requirement for ferroelectric and SHG properties is that the material must be NCS. For inorganic oxide crystals based on two types of building units of d0 transition metals and lone-pair-containing cations, the crystallographic noncentrosymmetry derives from their inherent asymmetric coordination environment due to second-order Jahn–Teller distortion. For metal–organic frameworks, there are several approaches to obtain NCS crystalline solids. One common synthetic strategy is the use of chiral organic linkers or chiral additives. The noncentrosymmetry of these chiral organic linkers can be transferred to the inorganic–organic hybrid frameworks. In contrast, another new strategy to obtain NCS materials is to use achiral organic linkers as starting materials, in which case NCS structures are derived from the spontaneous resolution process. Compared with NCS inorganic materials, little attention has been paid to NCS inorganic–organic hybrid frameworks even though they have the advantage of containing both organic ligands and inorganic metal ions. Although some NCS coordination polymers have been reported, they commonly display no or small signals of related properties such as SHG and ferroelectricity.

Generally, chiral and noncentrosymmetric (NCS) MOFs usually exhibit NLO properties. When their space groups are among the 10 polar point groups C 1, C  s , C 2, C 2v , C 4, C 4v , C 3, C 3v , C 6, and C 6v , they can even simultaneously exhibit both second harmonic generation (SHG) and ferroelectricity properties. As is well-known, a basic requirement for ferroelectric and SHG properties is that the material must be NCS. For inorganic oxide crystals based on two types of building units of d0 transition metals and lone-pair-containing cations, the crystallographic noncentrosymmetry derives from their inherent asymmetric coordination environment due to second-order Jahn-Teller distortion. For metal-organic frameworks, there are several approaches to obtain NCS crystalline solids. One common synthetic strategy is the use of chiral organic linkers or chiral additives. The noncentrosymmetry of these chiral organic linkers can be transferred to the inorganic-organic hybrid frameworks. In contrast, another new strategy to obtain NCS materials is to use achiral organic linkers as starting materials, in which case NCS structures are derived from the spontaneous resolution process. Compared with NCS inorganic materials, little attention has been paid to NCS inorganic-organic hybrid frameworks even though they have the advantage of containing both organic ligands and inorganic metal ions. Although some NCS coordination polymers have been reported, they commonly display no or small signals of related properties such as SHG and ferroelectricity.

elements.content: Some structurally intriguing complexes based on a semirigid tridentate triphenylamine-based ligand (TIPA, tris[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-phenyl]amine) have been reported to exhibit additional functionalities such as good NLO properties. Compared with benzene- and triazine-centered triangular ligands, N-centered tripodal ligands have more movable “kinks” that allow the ligand to more easily meet the geometric needs of different metal ions. We believe that more centrosymmetric and NCS metal–organic frameworks can be assembled from this semirigid TIPA ligand and polycarboxylate ligands.

Compared with benzene- and triazine-centered triangular ligands, N-centered tripodal ligands have more movable "kinks" that allow the ligand to more easily meet the geometric needs of different metal ions. We believe that more centrosymmetric and NCS metal-organic frameworks can be assembled from this semirigid TIPA ligand and polycarboxylate ligands.

elements.clean_text: 1  Structures of the Carboxylic Acids and TIPA Ligand Used in This Work

elements.content: Herein, five noncentrosymmetric and chiral MOFs based on TIPA ligand, namely, {[Co(TIPA)(trans-chdc)(H2O)]·H2O} n (1), {[Ni(TIPA)(trans-chdc)(H2O)]·H2O} n (2), {[Co(TIPA)(seb)1/2](NO3)·H2O} n (3), {[Ni(TIPA)(seb)1/2](NO3)·H2O} n (4), {[Zn2(TIPA)(btc)OH]·4H2O} n (5), where TIPA is tris[4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-phenyl]amine, H3btc is 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, trans-H2chdc is trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, and H2seb is sebacic acid, were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions by varying the carboxylate anions and metal salts. Coincidentally, they all contain 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation based on (6,3) layers. The crystal structures, topological analyses, and thermal properties of these materials were studied. In addition, the photoluminescence, SHG, and ferroelectricity properties of complexes 1–5 are discussed in detail.

elements.content: The triangular ligand TIPA was synthesized according to the literature. All other reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The IR absorption spectra of the complexes were recorded in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 by means of a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets (5 mg of sample in 500 mg of KBr). C, H, and N analyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were obtained in a Bruker 500 MHz NMR spectrometer. XRD measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (1.5418 Å), with the X-ray tube operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Luminescence spectra for the solid samples were recorded on an AMINCO Bowman Series2 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature (25 °C). The emission decay lifetimes were measured on an Edinburgh Instruments FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate the SHG signal. The backward-scattered SHG light was collected by a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532-nm radiation. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded by a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer from 25 to 750 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in N2 atmosphere (N2 flow rate of 100 mL min–1). The electric hysteresis loops were recorded on a Precision Premier II ferroelectric tester from Radiant Technologies, Inc.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The triangular ligand TIPA was synthesized according to the literature. All other reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The IR absorption spectra of the complexes were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 by means of a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets (5 mg of sample in 500 mg of KBr). C, H, and N analyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were obtained in a Bruker 500 MHz NMR spectrometer. XRD measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (1.5418 Å), with the X-ray tube operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Luminescence spectra for the solid samples were recorded on an AMINCO Bowman Series2 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature (25 °C). The emission decay lifetimes were measured on an Edinburgh Instruments FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate the SHG signal. The backward-scattered SHG light was collected by a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532-nm radiation. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded by a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer from 25 to 750 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in N2 atmosphere (N2 flow rate of 100 mL min-1). The electric hysteresis loops were recorded on a Precision Premier II ferroelectric tester from Radiant Technologies, Inc.

elements.content: Red crystals of 1 were grown from the solvothermal reaction of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.073 g, 0.25 mmol), TIPA (0.066 g, 0.15 mmol), and trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid (chdcH2) (0.0255 g, 0.15 mmol) in the mixed solvent of N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) and H2O (1:2, v/v) in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The reaction mixture was heated at 120 °C for 3 days, and 1 was obtained in 80% yield based on TIPA. Anal. Calcd for C35H35N7O6Co: C, 59.32; H, 4.98; N, 13.84%. Found: C, 60.51; H, 4.83; N, 13.13%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3407m, 3123m, 2923m, 1517s, 1397m, 1305w, 1290w, 1124w, 1064m, 963w, 829m, 717w, 655m, 543w, 467w.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data of 1–5 were collected on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures of 1–5 were solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structure and then refined anisotropically using full-matrix least-squares procedures based on F 2 values using SHELXTL (version 6.10) crystallographic software. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1 of the . The topological analysis and some diagrams were produced using the TOPOS program.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray crystallographic data of 1-5 were collected on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures of 1-5 were solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structure and then refined anisotropically using full-matrix least-squares procedures based on F 2 values using SHELXTL (version 6.10) crystallographic software. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1 of the . The topological analysis and some diagrams were produced using the TOPOS program.

Single-crystal X-ray crystallographic analyses revealed that both 1 and 2 crystallize in the chiral orthorhombic space group P212121, even though all of the starting materials are achiral. Because 1 and 2 are isostructural, only the crystal structure of 1 is discussed in detail. In 1, each Co1 with a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry is six-coordinated by three N atoms from three different TIPA ligands and three O atoms, two of which (O1, O3c) are from two distinct trans-chdc2– ligands and one of which (O5) is from a terminal water molecule, as shown in Figure .

elements.content: Each Co center is connected to three different TIPA ligands and two individual trans-chdc2– ligands and can thus be regarded as a five-connecting node. The six-membered circuits within this net are responsible for the self-catenation (Figure b).

elements.content: The most striking feature of complexes 1 and 2 is the existence of 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation structures based on (6,3) layers (Figure a). Two sets of layers oriented toward the [1, −1, 0] and [1, 1, 0] directions are interconnected by trans-chdc ligands to form an unprecedented self-catenated 3D framework. The angle between the two adjacent inclined planes is 59.0°. Further insight into one circle of a layer shows that each circle is catenated with four other circles from two different layers in the other set. As a group, these five circles are interconnected by four trans-chdc2– ligands that adopt a bidentate bridging coordination mode through their monodentate carboxylate groups (Figure b). The Co···Co distance through the trans-chdc2– ligands is 10.31 Å. Remarkably, as illustrated in Figure c, viewed along the a axis, all trans-chdc2– ligands are accommodated in the channels of complex 1, wherein the tethering trans-chdc2– ligands are extended through the crystallographic symmetry to generate 2-fold homochiral right-handed [Co(trans-chdc)] n helices that are oriented along the a crystal direction (Figure d). The overall structure of 1 can thus be described as a combination of 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation and right-handed Co(trans-chdc) helical chains.

elements.content: We have previously reported two MOFs (Cambridge Structural Database refcodes UNAZL and UNAYUE) based on the TIPA ligand that were obtained by the self-assembly reaction of TIPA ligand with Co2+ and Cd2+ ions, respectively. The former is achiral, whereas the latter is chiral. Their structures are quite different because of the different coordination requirements of the central metal ions. The cobalt MOF is a 2D porous noninterpenetrating coordination network with CdI2 topology, whereas the cadmium MOF is a 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined polycatenated framework and crystallizes in space group C2, which is the same as complexes 3 and 4. As illustrated in Figure c, complex 3 can be regarded as the product of incorporating seb2– dianions into complex UNAZL, however, whereas both complex 3 and complex UNAYUE contain the same structural characteristics of 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined polycatenation structures based on (6,3) layers. Moreover, two sets of layers in their own framework orient toward the same direction. Thus, the seb2– dianion is used to make an achiral cobalt complex (UNAZL) with CdI2 topology transform into chiral cobalt complex 3, which features the same structural characteristics as the cadmium complex (UNAYUE).

elements.content: Complex 5 crystallized in the noncentrosymmetric space group Pna21. The asymmetric unit of 5 consists of two crystallographically independent Zn2+ ions, which Zn1 and Zn2 ions are bridged by the μ2-hydroxyl O atom to form a dinuclear zinc unit with a Zn···Zn separation of 3.5178(7) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Zn2(TIPA)(btc)(μ2-OH)]⋅4H2O} n  (5)

Complex 5 crystallized in the noncentrosymmetric space group Pna21. The asymmetric unit of 5 consists of two crystallographically independent Zn2+ ions, which Zn1 and Zn2 ions are bridged by the μ2-hydroxyl O atom to form a dinuclear zinc unit with a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separation of 3.5178(7) Å.

elements.content: The dimeric Zn2(μ2-OH) units are interconnected by btc3– anions in a trimonodentate coordination mode to form a highly undulating 2D [Zn2(btc)(OH)] n layer (Figure a). Each dinuclear Zn unit connects to three btc3– ligands, and each btc3– ligand connects three dinuclear Zn units; both can be viewed as three-connected nodes. These two nodes are topologically equivalent nodes representing either the dimeric zinc unit center or an average btc3– ligand position. Thus, this 2D layer can be simplified as a uninodal (6,3) net with 63-hcb topology (Figure S1, ). Viewed along the a axis, adjacent layers are packed in an orderly ABAB-type array (Figure b). Then, these mutual parallel layers further extend to a noninterpenetrated 3D supramolecular framework through TIPA ligands (Figure a). The distance between adjacent layers is ca. 10.12 Å.

elements.content: Each TIPA ligand connects to three individual Zn2+ ions or three individual dinuclear zinc units and also acts as a three-connected node. In the framework of 5, each dimeric zinc unit connects directly to three TIPA ligands and three btc3– ligands. This, therefore, defines a six-connected node based on the dimeric zinc unit. As determined by TOPOS software, the Schläfli symbol for this 3,3,6-connected trinodal network is (63)2(69·86), representing a relatively simple yet unprecedented self-penetrating topology (Figure b), which suggests that two types of (6,3) nets with 63-hcb topology coexist in this framework. From a topological point of view, this noncentrosymmetric 3,3,6-connected trinodal network can be regarded as the combination of two types of interconnected 2D (6,3) nets.

elements.content: Complex 5 was recently reported by Wu et al., who also analyzed the topology of the framework. They regarded the two distinct Zn2+ ions as 4-connected nodes and the TIPA and btc3– ligands as 3-connected nodes. Thus, they defined a 3,4-connected network with a Schläfli symbol of (5·62·82·9)(63·72·9)(73)(62·8). Such a structure seems rather complicated and does not allow the intrinsic characteristics within the framework of complex 5 to be expressed appropriately. In contrast, considering the dimeric zinc unit as a 6-connected node is more suitable for expressing the structural characteristics of 5 with the simple Schläfli symbol of (63)2(69·86), which prompted us to think that two distinct 63 layers might coexist. With this method, the common structural features of chiral or noncentrosymmetric MOFs based on TIPA ligands should be relatively easy to find. These results are useful for the design and synthesis of chiral or noncentrosymmetric MOFs constructed by triangle ligands.

elements.content: To further understand this complicated structure of 5, we neglected the btc3– ligands from the structure of 5. As depicted in Figure a, elimination of the btc3– ligands leaves a 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation based on wavelike (6,3) layers, of which the single layers of the subpolycatenation are constructed by dimeric Zn2(μ2-OH) units and TIPA ligands (Figure b), both of which can be treated as 3-connected nodes. The angle between the two adjacent inclined planes is 87.7°. Further insight into one window of a layer shows that each window is catenated with four other window from two different layers in the other set through Hopf links. Alternatively, each window can be described as encircling two rods passing through it (Figure S3, ). Then, two sets of layers oriented toward the [2, 0, 1] and [2, 0, −1] directions are interconnected by btc3– ligands to form a 3D noninterpenetrated network.

elements.content: The thermal stabilities of crystalline samples of 1–5 were analyzed from 25 to 750 °C min–1 under a nitrogen atmosphere flowing at a rate of 100 mL min–1 (Figure S4 of the ). For 1, a weight loss of 5.43% was observed in the temperature range of 22–114 °C, which corresponds to the loss of coordinated and lattice water molecules (5.1%). Its framework is stable up to ca. 364 °C, from which the framework of 1 undergoes rapid decomposition. Complex 2 has the same decomposition process as complex 1, and its framework remains stable up to ca. 310. For 3, the first weight loss of 2.75% from room temperature to 275 °C corresponds to the loss of all guest water molecules (calcd 2.64%). From 275 to 407 °C, the TGA curve of 3 passes through a flat area, whereupon the framework begins to collapse. The weight loss process of 4 is similar to that of 3, showing that the framework of 4 is stable up to ca. 371 °C. Before that temperature, the preliminary weight loss of about 3.3% is attributed to the loss of guest water molecules (calcd 2.64%). For 5, dehydration commences at ∼20 °C and is completed by ∼209 °C. The 8.04% observed mass loss is consistent with the loss of lattice water (8.27% calcd). The subsequent thermal behavior might represent the loss of μ2-hydroxyl groups and subsequent decomposition of the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis and XRPD Results

The thermal stabilities of crystalline samples of 1-5 were analyzed from 25 to 750 °C min-1 under a nitrogen atmosphere flowing at a rate of 100 mL min-1 (Figure S4 of the ). For 1, a weight loss of 5.43% was observed in the temperature range of 22-114 °C, which corresponds to the loss of coordinated and lattice water molecules (5.1%). Its framework is stable up to ca. 364 °C, from which the framework of 1 undergoes rapid decomposition. Complex 2 has the same decomposition process as complex 1, and its framework remains stable up to ca. 310. For 3, the first weight loss of 2.75% from room temperature to 275 °C corresponds to the loss of all guest water molecules (calcd 2.64%). From 275 to 407 °C, the TGA curve of 3 passes through a flat area, whereupon the framework begins to collapse. The weight loss process of 4 is similar to that of 3, showing that the framework of 4 is stable up to ca. 371 °C. Before that temperature, the preliminary weight loss of about 3.3% is attributed to the loss of guest water molecules (calcd 2.64%). For 5, dehydration commences at ~20 °C and is completed by ~209 °C. The 8.04% observed mass loss is consistent with the loss of lattice water (8.27% calcd). The subsequent thermal behavior might represent the loss of μ2-hydroxyl groups and subsequent decomposition of the framework.

elements.content:
The purities of compounds 1–5 were confirmed by powder XRD analyses, where the main peaks of the experimental spectra of 1–5 were essentially consistent with the simulated spectra (, Figures S5–S9).

Luminescent Properties

Considering that 5 is a d10 complex and is insoluble in common organic solvents, its photoluminescence properties as well as those of free TIPA ligand were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). The strongest excitation peak for TIPA ligand was observed at wavelengths from 370 to 490 nm (λmax = 403 nm upon excitation at 356 nm). Complex 5 exhibits an intense emission with a maximum at 413 nm upon excitation at 352 nm. Compared with the free TIPA ligands, complex 5 shows a slightly red-shifted emission band. The emission band of 5 can be ascribed to π–π* or π–n transitions within the molecular orbital manifolds of imidazolyl and phenyl rings of TIPA ligands. In addition, the emission decay lifetimes of TIPA ligand and complex 5 were monitored, and the curves were best fitted by biexponentials in the solid. The emission decay lifetimes of the TIPA ligand and complex 5 were found to be as follows: TIPA ligand, τ1 = 1.79 ns (56.99%) and τ2 = 4.67 ns (43.01%) (χ2 = 0.951, , Figure S10); complex 5, τ1 = 0.31 ns (63.06%) and τ2 = 2.45 ns (36.94%) (χ2 = 1.171, , Figure S11).

elements.content: Complex 5 crystallizes in the point group C 2v , which is one of the 10 polar point groups (C 1, C s , C 2, C 2v , C 4, C 4v , C 3, C 3v , C 6, and C 6v ). To detect the ferroelectricity of 5, the hysteresis loops of electric polarization were measured on powdered samples in pellets (Figure ). At 283 K, the remnant polarization (P r) is ca. 0.02 μC/cm2, the electric coercive field (E c) is 1.8 kV/cm, and the saturation of the spontaneous polarization (P s) is ca. 0.066 μC/cm2, which is smaller than that of [Zn(1,3-bibm)(D-ca)] n (P r = 0.052 μC/cm2, P s = 0.143 μC/cm2) and comparable to that of a crystal sample of [Zn(1,4-bimb)(d-ca)] n (P r = 0.022 μC/cm2, P s = 0.095 μC/cm2). They are all smaller than that of typical ferroelectric compounds (e.g., NaKC4H4O6·4H2O, Rochelle salt, usually P s = 0.25 μC/cm2).
elements.clean_text:
Ferroelectric Properties of Complex 5 

Complex 5 crystallizes in the point group C 2v , which is one of the 10 polar point groups (C 1, C  s , C 2, C 2v , C 4, C 4v , C 3, C 3v , C 6, and C 6v ). To detect the ferroelectricity of 5, the hysteresis loops of electric polarization were measured on powdered samples in pellets (Figure ). At 283 K, the remnant polarization (P r) is ca. 0.02 μC/cm2, the electric coercive field (E c) is 1.8 kV/cm, and the saturation of the spontaneous polarization (P s) is ca. 0.066 μC/cm2, which is smaller than that of [Zn(1,3-bibm)(D-ca)] n  (P r = 0.052 μC/cm2, P s = 0.143 μC/cm2) and comparable to that of a crystal sample of [Zn(1,4-bimb)(d-ca)] n  (P r = 0.022 μC/cm2, P s = 0.095 μC/cm2). They are all smaller than that of typical ferroelectric compounds (e.g., NaKC4H4O6⋅4H2O, Rochelle salt, usually P s = 0.25 μC/cm2).

elements.content: Considering that complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in chiral space group P212121, complexes 3 and 4 crystallize in chiral space group C2, and complex 5 crystallizes in noncentrosymmetric space group Pna21, their nonlinear optical properties were studied. Second harmonic generation (SHG) measurements on powder samples of 1–5 using 1064-nm radiation revealed that complexes 1 and 2 display modest SHG responses that are approximately 0.3 and 0.4 times that of urea, respectively [ca. 3 and 4 times that of KH2PO4 (KDP), where KDP is a commercially available NLO reference material and has an I 2ω value of ∼10 versus α-quartz]. The SHG responses of 3 and 4 are about the same as those of 1 and 2, respectively. Complex 5 has a very strong SHG response, with an SHG efficiency approximately the same as that of urea [ca. 10 times that of KDP], which confirms its acentricity as well as its potential as a second-order nonlinear optical material.
elements.clean_text:
Powder Second Harmonic Generation Results

Considering that complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in chiral space group P212121, complexes 3 and 4 crystallize in chiral space group C2, and complex 5 crystallizes in noncentrosymmetric space group Pna21, their nonlinear optical properties were studied. Second harmonic generation (SHG) measurements on powder samples of 1-5 using 1064-nm radiation revealed that complexes 1 and 2 display modest SHG responses that are approximately 0.3 and 0.4 times that of urea, respectively [ca. 3 and 4 times that of KH2PO4 (KDP), where KDP is a commercially available NLO reference material and has an I 2ω value of ~10 versus α-quartz]. The SHG responses of 3 and 4 are about the same as those of 1 and 2, respectively. Complex 5 has a very strong SHG response, with an SHG efficiency approximately the same as that of urea [ca. 10 times that of KDP], which confirms its acentricity as well as its potential as a second-order nonlinear optical material.

elements.content: In summary, five structurally intriguing coordination polymers have been synthesized by using a N-centered extended tripodal ligand and carboxylic ligands. It is noteworthy that they all contain 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation based on (6,3) layers. At the same time, they are chiral or noncentrosymmetric (NCS) and exhibit strong SHG responses, with 5 being ferroelectric at the same time. It is noteworthy that one of our previously reported cadmium complexes crystallizing in the chiral space group C2 also features a 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined polycatenation based on (6,3), Cd-TIPA layers. This prompts us to explore more MOFs containing 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation based on (6,3) layers constructed from TIPA ligand, which might have either ferroelectric or NLO properties, or both. This work might provide a feasible strategy for incorporating ferroelectricity and SHG into MOFs. To verify this strategy, subsequent works will be focused on the structures and properties of a series of coordination complexes constructed from TIPA with more polycarboxylate ligands and metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, five structurally intriguing coordination polymers have been synthesized by using a N-centered extended tripodal ligand and carboxylic ligands. It is noteworthy that they all contain 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation based on (6,3) layers. At the same time, they are chiral or noncentrosymmetric (NCS) and exhibit strong SHG responses, with 5 being ferroelectric at the same time. It is noteworthy that one of our previously reported cadmium complexes crystallizing in the chiral space group C2 also features a 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined polycatenation based on (6,3), Cd-TIPA layers. This prompts us to explore more MOFs containing 2D → 3D parallel/parallel inclined subpolycatenation based on (6,3) layers constructed from TIPA ligand, which might have either ferroelectric or NLO properties, or both. This work might provide a feasible strategy for incorporating ferroelectricity and SHG into MOFs. To verify this strategy, subsequent works will be focused on the structures and properties of a series of coordination complexes constructed from TIPA with more polycarboxylate ligands and metal ions.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stabilities of crystalline samples of 1–5 were analyzed from 25 to 750 °C min–1 under a nitrogen atmosphere flowing at a rate of 100 mL min–1 (Figure S4 of the ). For 1, a weight loss of 5.43% was observed in the temperature range of 22–114 °C, which corresponds to the loss of coordinated and lattice water molecules (5.1%). Its framework is stable up to ca. 364 °C, from which the framework of 1 undergoes rapid decomposition. Complex 2 has the same decomposition process as complex 1, and its framework remains stable up to ca. 310. For 3, the first weight loss of 2.75% from room temperature to 275 °C corresponds to the loss of all guest water molecules (calcd 2.64%). From 275 to 407 °C, the TGA curve of 3 passes through a flat area, whereupon the framework begins to collapse. The weight loss process of 4 is similar to that of 3, showing that the framework of 4 is stable up to ca. 371 °C. Before that temperature, the preliminary weight loss of about 3.3% is attributed to the loss of guest water molecules (calcd 2.64%). For 5, dehydration commences at ∼20 °C and is completed by ∼209 °C. The 8.04% observed mass loss is consistent with the loss of lattice water (8.27% calcd). The subsequent thermal behavior might represent the loss of μ2-hydroxyl groups and subsequent decomposition of the framework.

The purities of compounds 1–5 were confirmed by powder XRD analyses, where the main peaks of the experimental spectra of 1–5 were essentially consistent with the simulated spectra (, Figures S5–S9).

Luminescent Properties

Considering that 5 is a d10 complex and is insoluble in common organic solvents, its photoluminescence properties as well as those of free TIPA ligand were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). The strongest excitation peak for TIPA ligand was observed at wavelengths from 370 to 490 nm (λmax = 403 nm upon excitation at 356 nm). Complex 5 exhibits an intense emission with a maximum at 413 nm upon excitation at 352 nm. Compared with the free TIPA ligands, complex 5 shows a slightly red-shifted emission band. The emission band of 5 can be ascribed to π–π* or π–n transitions within the molecular orbital manifolds of imidazolyl and phenyl rings of TIPA ligands. In addition, the emission decay lifetimes of TIPA ligand and complex 5 were monitored, and the curves were best fitted by biexponentials in the solid. The emission decay lifetimes of the TIPA ligand and complex 5 were found to be as follows: TIPA ligand, τ1 = 1.79 ns (56.99%) and τ2 = 4.67 ns (43.01%) (χ2 = 0.951, , Figure S10); complex 5, τ1 = 0.31 ns (63.06%) and τ2 = 2.45 ns (36.94%) (χ2 = 1.171, , Figure S11).
